abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Railways Project in Kenya. The
            objectives of the project were: (i) achieving the needed
            organizational restructuring and greater commercial
            orientation on Kenya Railways (KR); and (ii) revitalizing
            KR's operational performance. The objectives were clear
            and unambiguous, and at the same time, they left sufficient
            room for flexibility in project implementation. However, the
            cultural change required by the first objective was very
            demanding in the economic environment prevailing in the
            earlier stages of the project. The second objective aimed at
            improving financial results and reducing costs by improving
            KR's operations, primarily by actions to address
            weaknesses in locomotive maintenance and operational
            planning. Lessons Learned from the Project: (i) The
            borrower's commitment to major structural change needs
            to be positively demonstrated before commencing project
            implementation; in this case, the  Memorandum of
            Understanding (MOU) remained a statement of good intentions
            till the mid-part of project implementation;(ii)important
            institutional problems, (like, in this case, the locomotive
            maintenance delivery system) need to be addressed with
            fundamental reform which could include involvement of the
            private sector; (iii) client ownership of Technical
            Assistance (TA), periodical evaluation of TA performance and
            its linkage with absorption capacity are essential for
            success; (iv) arrival of TA personnel need to be
            synchronized with availability of inputs like spares; (v)
            spares procurement should be in manageable tranches, take
            into account the need for proprietary sources for critical
            items, and be done by a specialized agency, in case in-house
            expertise is inadequate; and (vi) equipment specification
            should emphasize proven experience in a similar working environment.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Railway Project supports
            Government efforts to lower transportation costs by
            promoting efficiency in the railway system.  It will also
            help the Kenya Railways Corporation (KR) realize its
            economic role as a carrier of long distance and bulk cargo
            and main carrier of traffic for the landlocked countries.
            In this context, the project entails three components.  They
            include (a) institutional development which involves the
            reorientation of Kenya Railway's management toward more
            commercial practices, introduction of modern management
            skills, and human resource development; and (b) increased
            motive power through the purchase of locomotive spare parts,
            improved locomotive repair and maintenance, and training.
            Finally, the project provides for (c) improved train
            operations through organizational changes, minor capital
            investments, and technical assistance.  The proposed project
            is expected to benefit Kenya and its railway significantly.
            The main quantified economic benefit expected to derive from
            the project are savings in transportation costs.
